content:
• Tuesday, July 5, 2016
  • GBIM

    Globeimmune to delist from Nasdaq

    • GlobeImmune (OTC:GBIM) -47.2% AH after announcing it will voluntarily delist and deregister its common stock from the Nasdaq.
    • GBIM cites its inability to find a suitable strategic transaction after a year-long process, a non-compliance letter from Nasdaq for continued listing requirements, and the listing and administrative costs associated with being a publicly listed company.
    • GBIM said in issuing its Q1 results that it had sufficient cash to continue as a going concern through mid-2017 but that it could decide to wind down operations if a strategic alternative was not found in the near future.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:57 PM | 19 Comments
  • JLL

    JLL closes purchase of workplace technology firm BRG

    • JLL (JLL -3.5%) has closed on its latest acquisition, of workplace technology firm BRG.
    • BRG chief Traci Doane will take over a new Technology Solutions service line at JLL, incorporating tech consulting and Integrated Workplace Management Systems.
    • BRG's space and occupancy planning, move and relocation management and project management services will become corresponding parts of JLL's suite in those areas.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:11 PM
  • RPM

    RPM International buys waterproofing product maker

    • RPM International (RPM -1.6%) has acquired assets of Duram Industries, an Australian maker of commercial waterproofing materials.
    • Terms weren't disclosed, though RPM expects the deal to be accretive to earnings within a year. It's acquiring the assets for its Tremco Group.
    • Duram's products supply waterproofing capability to brick, exterior insulation and finish systems, stucco and noise suppression walls, and generate annual net sales of about $6M.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:39 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: QUNR +18.1%. GRMN +13.6%. ABBV +4.0%. YY +3.2%. QRVO +2.1%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: IBN -15.8%. NUS -10.3%. GSK -3.3%. CIG -1.7%. KOPN -1.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM | 4 Comments
  • BRS

    Bristow Group chief administrative officer leaves company

    • Bristow Group (BRS -5.4%) says its chief administration officer, senior VP Hilary Ware, has left the company for personal reasons.
    • Mary Wersebe will serve as acting CAO while the company works to reorganize the role and responsibilities (it says that work is well under way).
     
     
     
     
    | 5:19 PM
  • VTR

    Ventas makes $1.5B portfolio purchase

    • The $1.5B cash deal is for all of the life science and medical real estate assets of Wexford Science & Technology from a fund managed by Blackstone.
    • The 25 class-A properties leased to universities and research companies will add a related business line to Ventas' (NYSE:VTR) portfolio.
    • The purchase is expected to close in Q4. It's expected to be accretive to normalized FFO per share by $0.07-$0.09.
    • In conjunction with the deal, the company is raising money with the sale of 9M shares of common stock.
    • Shares flat after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:55 PM | 5 Comments
  • DLR

    Digital Realty wraps $874M data-center buy from Equinix

    • Digital Realty (DLR +2.1%) has completed an $874M acquisition of eight European data centers from Equinix (EQIX -0.2%).
    • That deal is part of a divestment that Equinix undertook as a condition requested by the European Commission, tied to Equinix's purchase of TelecityGroup.
    • Equinix also entered a deal with Digital Realty to pay €189.75M for Digital Realty's operating business in St. Denis, Paris, including real estate and data center there.
    • Digital Realty's purchase comes at a multiple of about 13 times the portfolio's expected 2016 EBITDA. It includes five properties in London, two in Amsterdam and one in Frankfurt, and provides about 6.9 megawatts of fully installed power and 62,700 net sellable square feet.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:54 PM | 4 Comments
  • C

    Averages bounce late, but no mercy for financials

    • Interest rates continue to plummet, with U.S. government yields on the long end hitting new all-time lows. At least they remain positive (for now). Yields on French government paper are now negative all the way out to nine years, and Swiss 50-year bonds now sport yields below zero.
    • Some hawkish words today from San Francisco Fed President Williams weren't enough to lift the share prices of yield-starved financials (XLF -1.5%).
    • The SPDR KBW Bank ETF (KBE -3%), the SPDR KBW Regional Bank ETF (KRE -3%)
    • Citigroup (C -3.3%), Morgan Stanley (MS -3.5%), Regions Financial (RF -3.9%), Fifth Third (FITB -4.2%), Capital One (COF -3.3%), Legg Mason (LM -3.3%), E*Trade (ETFC -3.2%), Schwab (SCHW -3%), MetLife (MET -4.2%), Prudential (PRU -3.2%), Lincoln (LNC -4.5%)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM | 6 Comments
  • STNG

    Scorpio Tankers reiterated Buy at Deutsche Bank

    • Scorpio Tankers (STNG -3.6%) is reiterated with a Buy rating a $9 price target at Deutsche Bank, advising investors to buy shares on weakness even as the firm expects the company to miss Q2 earnings estimates.
    • In support of its positive view, Deutsche Bank says STNG trades at just 4.4x its revised 2017 EPS estimate, it views the 11.5% dividend yield as sustainable and secure, and the stock's 35% discount to net asset value, which incorporates realistic asset value assumption and $300M in remaining capex commitments.
    • Meanwhile, the firm cuts its EPS expectation to $0.42 from $0.83 for the current year and to $1.00 for 2017 from the earlier expectation of $1.16, reflecting lower product tanker rate assumptions.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:28 PM | 6 Comments
  • DVN

    Devon Energy target raised to $45 at Deutsche Bank, as asset quality wins

    • Devon Energy (DVN -3.7%) is reiterated with a Buy rating but at a raised $45 price target, up from $41, at Deutsche Bank, which views DVN as holding one of the deepest, highest quality, and still underappreciated asset portfolios among its E&P coverage.
    • While the market has wrestled with the overhang of debt and legacy cost structure, Deutsche Bank believes that DVN's better than expected execution on asset sales, peer-leading leverage to the next $10/bbl move in crude and advantaged exposure to the Delaware Basin and STACK provide a visible, revisions-driven path toward the firm's eventual bull case for the shares at $69.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:18 PM | 1 Comment
  • INFO

    Combined IHS/Markit to trade on Nasdaq as INFO

    • IHS (IHS -1.6%) and Markit (MRKT -1.6%) say their trading symbol for the merged "IHS Markit" company will be INFO, on Nasdaq.
    • The two have planned a $13B merger at which point the company will redomicile in London (IHS is headquartered currently in Englewood, Colo.).
    • Both companies are holding special meetings on Monday to vote on merger-related details. Approvals mean the companies will complete the merger Tuesday (July 12), and expect to begin trading under INFO on Wednesday, July 13.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:11 PM

  • Technology - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 3:00 pm

    • Gainers: LEDS +39%. PNTR +8%. HIMX +7%. DMRC +6%.
    • Losers: OTC:GIGA -12%. LLNW -11%. CBR -10%. HMNY -9%. IDN -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM
  • COG

    Cabot Oil inks 10-year deal to supply Pennsylvania power plant

    • Cabot Oil & Gas (COG -2.4%) says it has executed a 10-year sales agreement to be the exclusive provider of natural gas supplies to Invenergy's proposed Lackawanna Energy Center power plant in Pennsylvania.
    • Also, South Jersey Industries (SJI -0.3%) will become a counterparty to both entities through an exclusive supply fuel management service agreement.
    • The facility will burn up to 240K dekatherms of natural gas per day at maximum capacity; commercial operations are expected to begin in mid-2018 and to reach full-scale operations by year-end 2018.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM | 3 Comments

  • Losses grow in afternoon action

    • The S&P 500 (-1%) and Nasdaq (-1.3%) are at session lows with just a little more than an hour to go to the close.
    • The move comes following a near-2% tumble in Europe (though the U.K. posted a small gain), with the British pound taking out new 31-year lows.
    • As for bond yields, they continue to plumb new records, including the U.S. 10-year, which touched 1.36% earlier (1.37% now).
    • Oil, meanwhile, fell 5% to $46.60 per barrel, while gold and silver hit their strongest prices since 2014.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:57 PM | 1 Comment
  • OZM

    Och-Ziff AUM continue to decline

    • AUM fell 7.5% to $39.2B in June. For the entire quarter, AUM fell 6.7%, and for all of H1, they fell 12.1%.
    • Performance: All three of Och-Ziff's (OZM -5.3%) flagship funds turned in negative returns in Q2.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:45 PM | 4 Comments
  • PCAR

    Truckmaker stocks lower with EU fine overhang in play

    • Truckmakers face heavy fines from the European Union over price fixing charges, according to Bloomberg.
    • Although some truck manufacturers have set aside provisions to pay for the expected penalties, it's unclear which companies will end up having the largest exposure.
    • The sector is down across the board on the day, including PACCAR (NASDAQ:PCAR) -3.1%, Navistar (NYSE:NAV) -9.1%, Daimler (OTCPK:DDAIF) -5.4%, Volvo (OTCPK:VOLVY) ADRS -6.1%, Supreme Industries (NYSEMKT:STS) -8.5%, and CNH Industrial (NYSE:CNHI) -6.6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:18 PM | 1 Comment

  • Energy/Materials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: DRD +11%. GORO +9%. AKG +8%. GPL +9%. KGC +7%.
    • Losers: UNT -19%. ECR -16%. GLF -16%. CRC -15%. WLL -13%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:00 PM | 5 Comments
  • BB

    BlackBerry -2.7%; ending production of Classic line

    • BlackBerry (BBRY) hasn't moved entirely out of phones just yet, but it is leaving behind a Classic.
    • The company won't make its Classic line anymore, preferring to focus on "innovating and advancing" the portfolio.
    • Shares have fallen 2.7% so far today.
    • The Classic "has been an incredible workhorse device for customers, exceeding all expectations. But, the Classic has long surpassed the average lifespan for a smartphone in today’s market," says COO Ralph Pini in a post. "We are ready for this change so we can give our customers something better – entrenched in our legacy in security and pedigree in making the most productive smartphones."
    • The move is yet another step toward leaving behind the BB10 operating system, but Pini says the company still actively supports BlackBerry 10 and is on track to deliver 10.3.3 next month and another update to follow next year.
    • BlackBerry sold 500,000 devices in the most recent quarter, compared with 600,000 the quarter prior.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:57 PM | 90 Comments

  • Financials - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 1:00 PM

    • Gainers: YRD +6%.
    • Losers: OCN -17%. RESI -11%. ENVA -11%. AEG -11%. WAC -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: LEDS +58%. LBIX-OLD +17%. DRD +11%. SPU +11%. SPNE +11%. INSY +10%. PNTR +8%. PGNX +7%. AKG +7%. MZOR +7%.
    • Losers: XBIT -31%. AMDA -31%. DHR -22%. UNT -18%. OCN -17%. GNRT -16%. ECR -15%. GLF -15%. ASPS -15%. CANF -15%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:50 PM
  • CMCSA

    Netflix turns higher on deal with Comcast

    • Kara Swisher reports Comcast (CMCSA -0.7%) will let viewers stream Netflix (NFLX +1.4%) on its own interactive X1 platform.
    • Sources say the deal will be similar to arrangements Netflix has with smaller cable operators in this country and larger ones elsewhere that allow it (for a price) access to a large group of potential customers.
    • For Comcast, it will have an offering more competitive with those from Roku, Verizon, and Dish which already have apps from services like Netflix and Hulu.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:38 PM | 18 Comments
  • TOT

    Total names former refining head to run new gas and renewables unit

    • Total (TOT -2.9%) selects Philippe Sauquet, the former boss of its refining and chemicals division, to lead its newly created gas, renewables and power unit, in a sign that it sees potential growth in the division.
    • The nomination follows TOT’s expansion in cleaner energy, beginning with the 2011 acquisition of solar-panel maker SunPower and continuing with the May announcement of a $1.1B deal to buy French battery maker Saft.
    • Bernard Pinatel, a former executive at Bostik adhesives business when TOT agreed to sell the unit two years ago, will succeed Sauquet as president of refining and chemicals.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:23 PM

  • Third U.K. asset manager halts withdrawals; Europe down almost 2%

    • M&G Investments suspends action on the £4.4B Property Portfolio fund, making it the third U.K. asset manager to do so after the Brexit vote sparked a flurry of redemptions.
    • Source: Bloomberg
    • Aviva Investors suspending trading in a fund earlier today, and Standard Life did the same yesterday.
    • The pound (NYSEARCA:FXB) continues to tumble, now off a full 2% today vs. the dollar at $1.3020. At least in nominal terms the FTSE (NYSEARCA:EWU) is doing fine, closing higher by 0.35% today while broader European markets (NYSEARCA:FEZ) fell nearly 2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:55 AM | 12 Comments
  • OCN

    Ocwen complex tumbles

    • There's no news immediately evident, but Ocwen Financial (OCN -17.2%), Altisource Portfolio Solutions (ASPS -12.9%), Altisource Asset Management (AAMC -7.4%), and Altisource Residential (RESI -10.8%) are all sharply lower, with Ocwen and ASPS just coming off volatility-related trading halts.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:33 AM | 23 Comments
  • EYPT

    Preclinical studies show pSivida's Durasert implant delivering TKI just as effective as injection of FDA-approved biologic in wet AMD; shares up 5%

    • Thinly traded micro cap pSivida (PSDV +5.4%) bucks the market's bearishness. Shares are up on average volume (only ~23K shares so far) in response to its announcement of positive results from preclinical animal studies assessing the effectiveness of a sustained-release insert based on its Durasert technology to deliver a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) for the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD).
    • The data showed the TKI insert was similar in efficacy to an injection of an FDA-approved AMD biologic in preventing choroidal neovascularization (formation of new blood vessels) and reducing vascular leakage.
    • Based on the encouraging results, the company intends to advance the Durasert TKI insert into clinical development.
    • TKIs are currently used to treat cancer, but some inhibit a growth factor called PDGF (platelet-derived growth factor) which plays a key role in blood vessel formation. The TKI used by pSivida inhibits both PDGF and VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor). AMD meds Lucentis (ranibizumab) and Eylea (aflibercept) are both VEGF inhibitors. In cancer, TKIs are taken orally because systemic administration is too toxic. PSivida's approach aims to deliver a TKI dose directly to the retina that is 1,000 times less that the dose used to treat cancer.
    • Related tickers: (OTCQX:RHHBY -1.5%)(REGN -0.5%)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:16 AM | 2 Comments

  • Healthcare - Top Gainers / Losers as of 11:00 am

    • Gainers: INSY +13%. SPNE +10%. DHRM +9%. PGNX +8%. ADMP +7%.
    • Losers: XBIT -38%. AMDA -30%. CANF -20%. ONTX -12%. ARGS -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:00 AM
  • HIMX

    Himax Technologies +7% following upside guidance, CTO clarification

    • Himax Technologies (HIMX +6.7%) is sharply higher in early trading after pre-announcing upside Q2 results and issuing a clarification of Friday's news that its CTO had resigned.
    • HIMX says its Q2 (June) EPS exceeded guidance and that revenues and gross margin came in at the high end of guidance; Q2 sales rose 11.5% Q/Q to $201M compared to prior guidance of a 7.5%-12.5% gain, gross margin was 26.1% vs. prior guidance of "around 26%;" and GAAP EPS was $0.12 vs. guidance of $0.09-$0.11.
    • HIMX says its Q2 revenue increase was due to strong sales in its small- and medium-sized driver business, and smartphone driver integrated circuits experienced "phenomenal" growth due to Chinese end-brand customers gaining share from new model launches.
    • Separately, HIMX says the retirement of CTO Chih-Chung Tsai will not impact its business and technology development.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:37 AM | 2 Comments
  • DAL

    Delta Air Lines leads airline sector lower

    • Airline stocks are notable laggards on the day after Delta Air Lines (DAL -4.4%) reduced its outlook for Q2 operating margin to 17% (from 21% to 23% prior) and reported on a 5% drop in PRASM during June.
    • United Continental (UAL -3.5%) and American Airlines Group (AAL -2.5%) are seen as suffering from some of the same F/X and Brexit pressures abroad, while Spirit Airlines (SAVE -4%) and Allegiant Travel (ALGT -2.2%) continue their jittery trading patterns.
    • Southwest Airlines (LUV -1.4%) is also lower, despite a positive weekend profile in Barron's highlighting the stronger balance sheet the airline company has compared to peers and the lack of European headaches.
    • Previously: Delta Air Lines lower after issuing June traffic numbers (July 5)
    • Related ETF: JETS.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:35 AM | 5 Comments
  • CRUS

    Lower iPhone estimates in hand, Pac Crest downgrades CRUS, SWKS

    • Cirrus Logic (NASDAQ:CRUS) is off 7.4% and Skyworks Solutions (NASDAQ:SWKS) down 5.6% as Pacific Crest downgrades both to Sector Weight amid some disappointing iPhone supply chain forecasts.
    • Qorvo (QRVO -5.5%) and InvenSense (INVN -5.1%) are down as well.
    • Pac Crest has a fair value range of Cirrus Logic of $33-$36 (vs. its previous close of $38.04) and for $60-$67 on Skyworks (vs. previous close of $62.60).
    • It also cut price targets on Analog Devices (ADI -1.7%) to $60 from $62 (7.7% upside); Broadcom (AVGO -2.5%) to $180 from $185 (19.7% upside) and Qualcomm (QCOM -1.3%) to $59 from $61 (12.8% upside).
    • "Our lowered estimates reflect a much more disappointing second-half 2016 iPhone 7 ramp than what we had previously expected, as feedback from Asia indicates units are expected to be down 15% to 20% as compared to the iPhone 6s, as Apple appears to be taking a much more cautious view of the ramp," the analysts wrote.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:18 AM | 6 Comments
  • NWBO

    Northwest Bio inks equity deal with institutional investors; shares down 17%

    • Nano cap Northwest Biotherapeutics (OTCQB:NWBO -16.6%) enters into agreements with two institutional investors for the direct placement of 7.4M shares of common stock at $0.50 a share plus five-year warrants to purchase up to 3.7M shares of common at $0.60.
    • The deal should close today.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:11 AM | 10 Comments

  • New highs for gold

    • The yellow metal is up 1.15% to $1,354 per ounce, taking out the high hit during its immediate post-Brexit spike. The move comes as stocks slump - except for the FTSE 100, ahead 0.4% as the pound moves to new multi-decade lows vs. the dollar.
    • Gold bulls are also mulling the Bank of England's near-promise to cut rates this summer and consider a fresh round of QE. The metal hasn't held above the $1,350 level for any serious length of time for more than two years.
    • ETFs: GLD, IAU, PHYS, SGOL, UGL, DGP, GTU, UGLD, GLL, DZZ, GLDI, OUNZ, DGL, DGZ, DGLD, GYEN, GEUR, UBG, QGLDX
     
     
     
     
    | 10:09 AM | 15 Comments
  • PBR

    Petrobras puts nine shallow-water oil fields up for sale

    • Petrobras (PBR -6.5%) says it is putting nine small, shallow-water oil fields up for sale, as it continues to chip away at its ~$126B debt load.
    • The nine fields had an average production of 13K boe/day in 2015, representing just 0.5% of PBR's total production, but the sale is another step forward in its efforts to shed non-core assets as part of its $15B divestment plan.
    • "The fields are junk," a source tells Reuters, as their age will require substantial investment to maintain commercially viable output, "though almost anybody can run them cheaper than Petrobras."
     
     
     
     
    | 9:56 AM | 6 Comments
  • HOG

    Harley-Davidson gives back some buyout rumor gains

    • Shares of Harley-Davidson (NYSE:HOG) are peeling off some of their merger rumor gains in early action today.
    • Wall Street has been relatively quiet on how investors should react to the buyout development, but Seeking Alpha contributors are weighing in. The Value Investor has a detailed breakdown on how KKR can derive solid returns even if pays out $65 per share in a HOG takeover, while Economics-Based Investors issued a warning on buying the rumor.
    • HOG -6.01% premarket to $50.95.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:25 AM | 3 Comments

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers as of 9:10 am

    • Gainers: INSY +19%. BCRX +11%. HIMX +9%. VGZ +5%.
    • Losers: AMDA -27%. CANF -18%. AEG -9%. PUK -8%. XBIT -9%. LYG -7%. AV -7%. FCAU -6%. RBS -6%. PLG -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:15 AM | 1 Comment

  • Pound takes out post-Brexit lows

    • Cable (NYSEARCA:FXB) is lower by 1.65% today to $1.3061 - taking out by a decent margin the panicky lows set following the shock Brexit vote. Alongside that move vs. the dollar, the pound has also tumbled to nearly a three-year low against the euro (NYSEARCA:FXE).
    • It's leading to interesting action in equities, with the FTSE 100 (NYSEARCA:EWU) cruising along to a modest gain today, while Europe's Stoxx 50 (NYSEARCA:FEZ) tumbles 1.5%, led by a 1.6% decline in German (NYSEARCA:EWG).
    • The Bank of England's Mark Carney late last week more or less promised a rate cut this summer, and hinted at more QE, if necessary.
    • ETFs: VGK, HEDJ, FEZ, IEV, EPV, EZU, FEU, EURL, DBEU, EEA, FEP, HEZU
     
     
     
     
    | 9:05 AM | 3 Comments
  • AMDA

    Amedica prices $11M equity offering; shares off 20% premarket

    • Nano cap Amedica (NASDAQ:AMDA) drops 20% premarket on robust volume in response to its announcement that it has priced its public equity offering at a discount to Friday's close of $1.32.
    • The offering consists of Class A Units and Class B Units. Each Class A Unit, priced at $1.00, consists of one share of common stock and one five-year warrant to purchase one share of common at $1.00. Each Series B Unit, priced at $1,000, consists of one share of preferred stock that is convertible into 1,000 shares of common stock and 1,000 warrants to purchase 1,000 shares of common stock (price undisclosed).
    • A total of 3.608M shares of common stock, 7,392 shares of convertible preferred stock and warrants to purchase 11M shares of common stock will be issued in the offering.
    • Underwriters over-allotment is an additional 1.65M shares of common stock and/or additional warrants to purchase up to 1.65M shares of common. Closing date is July 8.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:03 AM
  • ILMN

    Ilumina slumps 4% premarket on MS downgrade

    • Ilumina (NASDAQ:ILMN) is off 4% premarket on light volume. The only news is a downgrade by Morgan Stanley to Underweight with a price target of $110 (22% downside risk).
     
     
     
     
    | 8:48 AM | 2 Comments
  • INSY

    FDA approves Insys Therapeutics' Syndros for anorexia weight loss and CINV; shares ahead 21% premarket

    • Insys Therapeutics (NASDAQ:INSY) is up 21% premarket on robust volume in response to its announcement that the FDA has approved its dronabinol oral solution, Syndros, for the treatment of anorexia-associated weight loss in patients with AIDS and the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) in patients who have not responded to conventional antiemetic treatments.
    • It is the first dronabinol solution approved in the U.S.
    • Syndros is a liquid formulation of the pharmaceutical cannabinoid, dronabinol, a synthetic version of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). It is awaiting scheduling by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration.
    • Read now Insys Therapeutics Is Hoping Syndros Is Its Blockbuster Marijuana Ticket 
     
     
     
     
    | 8:39 AM | 3 Comments
  • CANF

    Can-Fite Bio's lead product candidate flunks mid-stage glaucoma study; shares down 23% premarket

    • Thinly traded nano cap Can-Fite BioPharma (NYSEMKT:CANF) slumps 23% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement that lead product candidate CF101 (Piclidenoson) failed to beat placebo in a Phase 2 clinical trial investigating CF101's ability to lower intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients.
    • CEO Pnina Fishman, Ph.D., says, "We are disappointed that CF101 failed to meet its primary endpoint and based on these overall results we see no immediate path forward in glaucoma."
    • CF101 is also under development for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and plaque psoriasis.
    • CF101 is an anti-inflammatory oral small molecule drug. Its mechanism of action is mediating A3 adenosine receptors, key signalling proteins which play key roles in the production of inflammatory cytokines.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:15 AM | 3 Comments
  • ISCA

    International Speedway misses by $0.03, beats on revenue

    • International Speedway (NASDAQ:ISCA): Q2 EPS of $0.29 misses by $0.03.
    • Revenue of $167.56M (+2.2% Y/Y) beats by $4.56M.
    • Shares +2.28% PM.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:32 AM
